diseases.description: A fungal disease that makes dark, rough spots on apple leaves and fruits.
diseases.causes: Caused by a fungus that grows in cool and wet weather, especially on fallen old leaves.
diseases.symptoms: Olive-green to black spots on leaves, rough scabby patches on apple skin, leaves may curl or drop early.
diseases.solution: Remove and destroy fallen leaves, prune the tree for good air flow. Use organic copper or sulfur-based fungicide as advised by the local agriculture officer.
diseases.prevention: Keep area under trees clean, avoid overhead watering, prune trees regularly, use disease-resistant varieties when possible.

pesticides.name: Organic copper fungicide (government-approved)

diseases.description: A disease that causes dark brown leaf spots and rotten areas on apple fruit.
diseases.causes: Caused by a fungus that survives on dead branches and mummified fruits left on the tree or ground.
diseases.symptoms: Purple or brown leaf spots with dark centers, cankers on branches, fruits show black ring-like rot.
diseases.solution: Prune and burn dead branches and old infected fruits, clean the orchard properly. Use organic copper-based spray if recommended locally.
diseases.prevention: Remove all mummified fruits after harvest, keep trees healthy with proper manure and pruning, avoid injuries to bark.

pesticides.name: Organic copper oxychloride (as per state agriculture department)

diseases.description: A disease that creates orange or yellow spots on apple leaves and can weaken the tree.
diseases.causes: Caused by a rust fungus that moves between apple trees and certain juniper/cedar trees.
diseases.symptoms: Bright yellow to orange spots on upper leaf surface, tube-like growths on lower leaf surface, early leaf fall.
diseases.solution: Remove nearby wild juniper or cedar hosts if possible. Use organic sulfur or copper-based rust control as advised.
diseases.prevention: Plant apples away from cedar or juniper, prune crowded branches to improve air movement, keep trees healthy with good organic manure.

pesticides.name: Wettable sulfur (organic-compatible) for rust control

diseases.description: A white powdery growth on cherry leaves that can reduce fruit quality.
diseases.causes: Caused by a fungus that likes warm, dry days with cool, humid nights.
diseases.symptoms: White powder-like layer on leaves, twisted or curled leaves, reduced fruit size and sweetness.
diseases.solution: Remove badly infected leaves, ensure good air flow in the canopy. Spray organic sulfur or neem-based product as recommended.
diseases.prevention: Avoid overcrowded planting, prune trees to keep open canopy, avoid excess nitrogen fertiliser.

pesticides.name: Neem oil-based bio-fungicide (certified organic)

diseases.description: A leaf disease of maize that causes rectangular gray lesions and reduces yield.
diseases.causes: Caused by a fungus that survives on infected crop residue and spreads in warm, humid weather.
diseases.symptoms: Small brown spots that grow into long gray rectangular lesions between veins, leaves may dry early.
diseases.solution: Use clean seed, destroy infected crop residue after harvest. In severe cases, use organic copper or bio-fungicide as advised.
diseases.prevention: Follow crop rotation, avoid continuous maize on same field, use resistant varieties when available, maintain balanced organic nutrition.

pesticides.name: Trichoderma viride bio-fungicide (recommended by agriculture departments)

diseases.description: A disease causing reddish-brown pustules on maize leaves.
diseases.causes: Caused by a rust fungus that spreads quickly through wind-blown spores in moist conditions.
diseases.symptoms: Small raised reddish-brown pustules on both sides of leaves, leaves may turn yellow and dry.
diseases.solution: Grow recommended resistant varieties, keep fields well spaced for air flow. Use organic sulfur or copper formulations if recommended by local experts.
diseases.prevention: Avoid late sowing, remove volunteer maize plants, maintain field hygiene and crop rotation.

pesticides.name: Wettable sulfur (organic-compatible) for rust management

diseases.description: A serious leaf disease of maize that reduces grain fill.
diseases.causes: Caused by a fungus that survives in infected residues and spreads in wet, cool conditions.
diseases.symptoms: Long, cigar-shaped gray or tan lesions on leaves, premature leaf drying, poor grain filling.
diseases.solution: Use clean, disease-free seed, remove infected residues by burning or deep ploughing. Use bio-fungicide like Trichoderma as per local guideline.
diseases.prevention: Rotate maize with non-host crops, avoid dense planting, use recommended resistant hybrids.

pesticides.name: Trichoderma-based bio-fungicide for seed and soil

diseases.description: A disease that causes dark spots on grape leaves and shriveled black berries.
diseases.causes: Caused by a fungus that survives in mummified berries and infected shoots left in the vineyard.
diseases.symptoms: Brown leaf spots with dark edges, shriveled black fruits hanging on the vine, cankers on shoots.
diseases.solution: Remove and destroy mummified berries and infected shoots, prune vines properly. Apply organic copper fungicide if suggested by experts.
diseases.prevention: Maintain open canopy by pruning, avoid overhead irrigation, follow good sanitation after harvest.

pesticides.name: Organic copper fungicide (as per local grape advisory)

diseases.description: A trunk disease of grapevine that causes leaf scorch and dark streaks in wood.
diseases.causes: Caused by a complex of wood-invading fungi entering through pruning wounds.
diseases.symptoms: Tiger-stripe pattern on leaves, dried leaf edges, black streaks in wood, weak vines.
diseases.solution: Avoid large pruning cuts, remove and destroy heavily infected vines. Use recommended trunk protection and organic wound sealants.
diseases.prevention: Prune during dry weather, disinfect tools, maintain vine vigor with good organic manures.

pesticides.name: Organic wound sealant or paste (locally recommended)

diseases.description: A leaf disease that causes irregular brown patches and defoliation in grapes.
diseases.causes: Caused by a fungus that spreads in warm and humid conditions.
diseases.symptoms: Irregular brown spots on leaves, yellowing and early leaf fall, reduced bunch size.
diseases.solution: Collect and destroy infected leaves, ensure good air circulation in vineyard. Use organic copper or bio-fungicide sprays if needed.
diseases.prevention: Avoid overhead irrigation, prune properly, keep vineyard floor clean from leaf litter.

pesticides.name: Pseudomonas fluorescens bio-fungicide (recommended in organic programs)

diseases.description: A serious bacterial disease that causes yellow shoots, misshapen fruits and tree decline.
diseases.causes: Spread by a small insect (psyllid) that carries the bacteria from tree to tree.
diseases.symptoms: Yellowing of leaves in patches, small lopsided fruits with bitter taste, thin canopy and decline.
diseases.solution: Remove and destroy severely infected trees, control the insect vector using organic-approved sprays. Use disease-free nursery plants.
diseases.prevention: Buy seedlings from certified nurseries, regularly monitor trees for symptoms, manage psyllids with neem-based formulations.

pesticides.name: Neem oil-based insecticide (approved for organic citrus)

diseases.description: A disease causing dark spots on peach leaves and fruits, leading to cracking.
diseases.causes: Caused by bacteria that spread through splashing rain and wind.
diseases.symptoms: Small dark spots on leaves with yellow halo, shot holes, rough spots and cracks on fruits.
diseases.solution: Prune trees to improve airflow, remove badly infected twigs. Use copper-based bactericide compatible with organic standards as per advice.
diseases.prevention: Avoid overhead irrigation, follow good field sanitation, use tolerant varieties if available.

pesticides.name: Copper hydroxide (used in many government recommendations, organic-compatible dose)

diseases.description: A bacterial disease of capsicum that causes leaf spots and fruit spots.
diseases.causes: Spread by contaminated seed, tools, splashing water and wind-driven rain.
diseases.symptoms: Small water-soaked spots on leaves that turn brown, shot holes, raised scabby spots on fruits.
diseases.solution: Use disease-free seed, remove infected plants early, avoid working in wet fields. Copper-based bactericides compatible with organic use can be applied on advice.
diseases.prevention: Use crop rotation, avoid overhead watering, disinfect seed or use certified seed.

pesticides.name: Copper oxychloride (used in many agricultural schemes, organic-compatible dose)

diseases.description: A common potato leaf disease that produces brown concentric spots.
diseases.causes: Caused by a fungus that survives in crop residues and soil.
diseases.symptoms: Brown circular spots with rings on older leaves, yellow area around spots, defoliation in severe cases.
diseases.solution: Remove infected leaves, avoid waterlogging, maintain proper spacing. Spray organic copper or bio-fungicide as per local recommendation.
diseases.prevention: Rotate potato with non-host crops, use healthy seed tubers, apply well-decomposed organic manure.

pesticides.name: Trichoderma-based bio-fungicide for soil and foliar use

diseases.description: A fast-spreading disease that causes dark blights on leaves and tuber rot.
diseases.causes: Caused by a water mold that spreads quickly in cool, wet weather.
diseases.symptoms: Water-soaked dark patches on leaves, white fungal growth under leaves in humid weather, tubers show brown rotten areas.
diseases.solution: Destroy heavily infected plants, avoid irrigation in late evening. Use copper-based fungicides allowed in organic farming under expert guidance.
diseases.prevention: Plant early where possible, ensure good drainage, use resistant varieties, avoid thick canopy from excess nitrogen.

pesticides.name: Copper hydroxide/copper oxychloride (as per government potato advisory)

diseases.description: A white powdery growth on squash leaves that reduces plant vigor.
diseases.causes: Caused by fungi that thrive in warm, dry weather with high humidity at night.
diseases.symptoms: White powder-like spots on upper surface of leaves, leaves may turn yellow and dry.
diseases.solution: Remove infected leaves, improve air movement. Spray neem oil or sulfur-based organic fungicide as recommended.
diseases.prevention: Avoid dense planting, keep plants well-spaced, avoid overuse of nitrogen.

pesticides.name: Neem oil-based fungicide (commonly promoted in organic programs)

diseases.description: A leaf disease of strawberry that causes reddish-brown spots and leaf drying.
diseases.causes: Caused by a fungus that survives on infected leaves and spreads with splashing water.
diseases.symptoms: Small purple spots that turn brown, leaves look burned at edges, reduced plant vigor.
diseases.solution: Remove infected leaves, avoid overhead irrigation. Use organic copper or bio-fungicide if disease pressure is high.
diseases.prevention: Use clean planting material, keep field free of weeds and old leaves, maintain proper spacing.

pesticides.name: Pseudomonas fluorescens bio-fungicide for foliar spray

diseases.description: A bacterial disease that causes small dark spots on tomato leaves and fruits.
diseases.causes: Spread by infected seed, tools, splashing rain and irrigation water.
diseases.symptoms: Small brown to black spots on leaves, shot holes, rough spots on green fruits.
diseases.solution: Use certified seed, remove diseased plants, avoid touching plants when wet. Use copper-based bactericide compatible with organic farming as advised.
diseases.prevention: Rotate crops, avoid overhead irrigation, practice good field sanitation.

pesticides.name: Copper hydroxide/copper oxychloride (use as per tomato advisory)

diseases.description: A common tomato disease that makes brown ringed spots on leaves.
diseases.causes: Caused by a fungus surviving in soil and plant residues.
diseases.symptoms: Brown spots with concentric rings on older leaves, yellow area around spots, defoliation, fruit spots near stem end.
diseases.solution: Remove lower infected leaves, stake plants to keep foliage dry, avoid overhead watering. Use organic copper or Trichoderma-based fungicide as needed.
diseases.prevention: Follow crop rotation, use healthy seedlings, apply well-rotted farmyard manure.

pesticides.name: Trichoderma harzianum bio-fungicide (seedling and soil treatment)

diseases.description: A serious disease of tomato causing water-soaked dark lesions and fruit rot.
diseases.causes: Caused by a water mold that spreads in cool, wet and cloudy conditions.
diseases.symptoms: Large dark patches on leaves and stems, white growth at lesion edges in humidity, brown firm rot on fruits.
diseases.solution: Remove and destroy infected plants and fruits, improve drainage, avoid dense planting. Use copper-based fungicide allowed under organic norms as per advice.
diseases.prevention: Avoid overhead irrigation, plant with good spacing, use resistant varieties where available.

pesticides.name: Copper oxychloride/copper hydroxide (as per tomato late blight advisory)

diseases.description: A disease that causes yellow patches on top of leaves and olive-green mold below.
diseases.causes: Caused by a fungus that spreads in high humidity, especially in protected structures.
diseases.symptoms: Yellow spots on upper leaf surface, olive-green fuzzy growth below, leaf curling and drop.
diseases.solution: Reduce humidity by ventilation, avoid overhead watering, remove infected leaves. Use organic-approved fungicide like copper or bio-fungicide as recommended.
diseases.prevention: Maintain proper spacing, improve air circulation, avoid frequent leaf wetting.

pesticides.name: Bio-fungicide (Trichoderma/Pseudomonas) foliar spray

diseases.description: A disease that causes many small spots on leaves and can defoliate plants.
diseases.causes: Caused by a fungus that survives on old tomato debris and spreads with water.
diseases.symptoms: Many tiny circular spots with dark borders and light centers on leaves, yellowing and dropping of leaves.
diseases.solution: Remove infected leaves, keep lower foliage dry, mulch soil to reduce splash. Use organic copper fungicide if disease is severe.
diseases.prevention: Rotate crops, avoid planting tomatoes near old debris, use drip irrigation instead of overhead.

pesticides.name: Copper-based fungicide (organic-compatible dose under guidance)

diseases.description: A pest problem where tiny mites suck sap and cause yellow, dry leaves.
diseases.causes: Caused by sap-sucking mites that increase in hot and dry weather.
diseases.symptoms: Very small yellow spots on leaves, fine webbing on underside, leaves turn yellow and dry.
diseases.solution: Spray water on underside of leaves to wash mites, remove heavily infested leaves. Use neem oil-based miticide suitable for organic farming.
diseases.prevention: Avoid dusty conditions, keep plants well watered (not waterlogged), encourage natural enemies by avoiding harsh chemicals.

pesticides.name: Neem oil-based bio-miticide (used in many organic pest programs)

diseases.description: A fungal disease that makes circular spots with concentric rings on tomato leaves.
diseases.causes: Caused by a fungus that spreads through splashing water and infected debris.
diseases.symptoms: Round brown spots with rings on leaves and fruits, yellow area around spots, leaf drop.
diseases.solution: Remove infected leaves and fruits, avoid overhead irrigation. Use bio-fungicide or organic copper products as per local advisory.
diseases.prevention: Practice crop rotation, keep field clean of debris, maintain proper spacing and pruning.

pesticides.name: Trichoderma-based bio-fungicide (recommended for tomato foliar diseases)

diseases.description: A viral disease that causes yellow, curled leaves and very low yield.
diseases.causes: Spread mainly by whitefly insects feeding on infected and healthy plants.
diseases.symptoms: Yellowing of young leaves, leaf curling upwards, stunted plants, very few and small fruits.
diseases.solution: Remove and destroy infected plants early, control whiteflies by using yellow sticky traps and neem-based sprays. Use virus-tolerant varieties where available.
diseases.prevention: Use insect-proof nets for nurseries, control whiteflies, avoid planting tomatoes near old infected crops.

pesticides.name: Neem oil-based insecticide (for whitefly management)

diseases.description: A viral disease that gives mosaic light and dark patterns on leaves.
diseases.causes: Spread by contact, tools, hands, and sometimes by seed.
diseases.symptoms: Mosaic light and dark green patterns on leaves, leaf distortion, reduced plant growth and yield.
diseases.solution: Remove infected plants, wash hands and tools after handling plants, avoid tobacco use in fields. There is no direct spray for virus, focus on hygiene and seed health.
diseases.prevention: Use certified virus-free seed, maintain strict field hygiene, disinfect tools regularly.

pesticides.name: Neem oil or soap solution for vector management if needed
